TITLE: On agile performance requirements specification and testing
ABSTRACT: Underspecified performance requirements can cause performance issues in a software system. However, a complete, upfront analysis of a software system is difficult, and usually not desirable. We propose an evolutionary model for performance requirements specifications and corresponding validation testing. The principles of the model can be integrated into agile development methods. Using this approach, the performance requirements and test cases can be specified incrementally, without big upfront analysis. We also provide a post hoc examination of a development effort at IBM that had a high focus on performance requirements. The examination indicates that our evolutionary model can be used to specify performance requirements such that the level of detail is commensurate with the nature of the project. Additionally, the IBM experience indicates that test driven development-type validation testing corresponding to the model can be used to determine if performance objectives have been met
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in the context of agile methodologies, specifically performance requirements specification and testing using an evolutionary model. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (through integration with agile development) (EC7), and answers at least one research question (on performance requirements and testing) (EC9). It meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements using agile methods (IC1), is a primary study (IC2), uses a mixed-methods approach (qualitative and quantitative elements) (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4).
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses performance requirements specification and testing in software projects using agile methodologies, which meets IC1. It is from IBM, a reputable industry, satisfying IC2. The article is qualitative in nature (as it examines a development effort), and it appears to be a primary study based on the IBM project examination, thus meeting IC3 and IC4. There is no indication of the article being written in a language other than English, being incomplete or just an abstract, being a tertiary or meta-analysis, dealing with teaching agile methods, failing to address agile methodologies, or failing to answer research questions. Therefore, it meets all the Inclusion Criteria without violating any Exclusion Criteria.

TITLE: A feasible user story tool for agile software development?
ABSTRACT: User stories form the heart of the Extreme Programming methodology planning game. In its turn, Extreme Programming is one of the supporting pillars of the wider agile software development process. The user stories form a set of central work products that determine the software development processes. In the spirit of Extreme Programming the production of user stories is kept as simple as possible. Traditionally, user stories are hand written on index cards as they are easy to store, display, rearrange and distribute to the co-located development team. However, virtually all other work products of an application development team are in electronic format, and agile software development is increasingly being adopted by teams working from remote locations. In these circumstances distributed development teams look to software solutions for creating and using user stories. This paper surveys some of the tools that are being used and examines their suitability for the task using a set of requirements. As a result of this investigation the author has produced a prototype user story software tool for Agile Software Development called DotStories. The paper concludes by discussing the features of DotStories and its how closely it can approach the ideal user story software tool. Indeed, the proposition that software tools can ever improve on index cards is considered in the light of experience to date.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile software development by evaluating user story tools and proposing a prototype tool (DotStories). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (Extreme Programming) (EC7), and answers at least one research question (suitability of tools for user stories) (EC9). It meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is from academia (IC2), is qualitative and quantitative in nature (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4).
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it is a qualitative research (IC3), and it is a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any of the exclusion criteria (EC1-EC9).

TITLE: Sprint: Agile specifications in Shockwave and Flash
ABSTRACT: Digital product development teams have trouble coordinating specification assets, both in the effort to represent a stable design in multiple specification forms, and particularly when a changing context causes requirement changes. The Agile process movement avoids cumbersome specifications by prescribing faster release cycles, more parallel development, and greater requirement flexibility.Sprint is both a method and a tool designed to allow an Agile approach to product development while supporting best practices for user-centered design. Unlike more comprehensive modeling and configuration management products, Sprint is for smaller teams to use for design and specification, and allows designers to stay synchronized with customers, analysts, and developers.Driven by Shockwave or Flash prototypes, Sprint links project assets, such as personas, scenarios, screen designs, storyboards, requirements, and use cases, to form interactive specifications. By eliminating asset redundancies and supporting multiple asset fidelities, Sprint reduced our administrative documentation tasks, accelerated client/user feedback, and improved team coordination.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in the context of agile methodologies, specifically focusing on agile specifications in product development using Shockwave and Flash. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (agile specifications and iterative development), and answers relevant research questions regarding team coordination and requirement management (EC9). It meets inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is from industry practice (IC2), and presents a qualitative case study (IC3 and IC4). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article does not violate any exclusion criteria: It is written in English (EC1). It addresses software requirements, specifically those related to agile methodologies (EC3). It is not described as incomplete, a draft, presentation slides, or just an abstract (EC4). It is not described as tertiary or a meta-analysis (EC5). It does not deal with teaching agile methods, but rather with the application of an agile methodology (EC6). It does not fail to address any agile methodologies; instead, it discuss

TITLE: Software product line scoping and requirements engineering in a small and medium-sized enterprise: An industrial case study
ABSTRACT: Abstract Software product line (SPL) engineering has been applied in several domains, especially in large-scale software development. Given the benefits experienced and reported, \{SPL\} engineering has increasingly garnered interest from small to medium-sized companies. It is possible to find a wide range of studies reporting on the challenges of running a \{SPL\} project in large companies. However, very little reports exist that consider the situation for small to medium-sized enterprises and these studies try develop universal truths for \{SPL\} without lessons learned from empirical evidence need to be contextualized. This study is a step towards bridging this gap in contextual evidence by characterizing the weaknesses discovered in the scoping (SC) and requirements (RE) disciplines of SPL. Moreover, in this study we conducted a case study in a small to medium sized enterprises (SMEs) to justify the use of agile methods when introducing the \{SPL\} \{SC\} and \{RE\} disciplines through the characterization of their bottlenecks. The results of the characterization indicated that ineffective communication and collaboration, long iteration cycles, and the absence of adaptability and flexibility can increase the effort and reduce motivation during project development. These issues can be mitigated by agile methods.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is written in English (IC1), addresses software requirements in agile methodologies within a small and medium-sized enterprise (IC1, IC2), and is based on an empirical industrial case study (IC3, IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is not in a non-English language (EC1), it addresses software requirements (EC3), it is not incomplete or a draft (EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), it addresses at least one agile methodology (implied by the discussion of agile methods mitigating bottlenecks, EC7), and it answers at least one research question (characterization of bottlenecks in scoping and requirements engineering, EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses SPL engineering in the context of small and medium-sized enterprises, which satisfies IC1. It is an industrial case study, meeting IC2. The research is qualitative, aligning with IC3. It is a primary study, not a secondary one, aligning with IC4. The article does not violate any Exclusion Criteria. It does not discuss teaching agile methods (EC6) or fail to address agile methodologies (EC7). It addresses the research questions regarding the challenges of SPL engineering in SMEs, meeting IC6. Therefore, the article is INCLUDED.

TITLE: A web-based model for simulating whole-farm beef cattle systems
ABSTRACT: This paper details the rationale and procedures included in a web-based simulator containing production of beef cattle and cash crops. All biophysical and economical definitions including management in terms of rules constitute user-defined scenarios, which can be saved, retrieved, modified and deleted. Herbage growth may be either provided by the user or estimated from daily climate information. Scenarios are simulated and their outcomes are sent to the user's e-mail as a spreadsheet file, including data and pre-designed graphs to facilitate the interpretation of results. An example simulation study of a grazing-based finishing beef steers with a cycle of 12 months is presented, where new weaners enter the system in the autumn. Increased stocking rates, \{SR\} (150, 170, 190 and 210 heads in a 100-ha farm) and different summer maize feeding (SMF) rates were compared (SMF0 = control and SMF1 = intermittent rule-driven maize feeding during summer). In this simulation study, â€œdeviationsâ€� from user-defined targets are simplified into two associated rules (a) average farm herbage mass deviation to adjust herbage allowance, and (b) target animal live weight deviation, associated to SMF1. The proportion of unfinished steers at 28th February increased linearly (p â‰¤ 0.01) with higher stocking rates and became zero at any stocking rate where the \{SMF\} rule was operating (SMF1). The economic response of SR Ã— SMF interaction was significant for gross margin, indicating a positive linear association (p â‰¤ 0.05) of \{SMF1\} treatment (rule activated) when \{SR\} increases. The potential use of the web simulator as a flexible tool for investigation, training and decision making are discussed.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements or agile methodologies, and does not relate to software project requirements in any way. It focuses on a web-based simulator for agricultural systems, which falls outside the scope of software project requirements using agile methodologies. Therefore, it violates EC3 and EC7, and fails to meet IC1.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies by presenting a web-based simulator for beef cattle systems. It specifies the use of user-defined scenarios and rules for managing herbage growth and stocking rates, which aligns with IC1. The study, while not explicitly stated as qualitative or quantitative, implies a quantitative approach through simulations and data analysis, meeting IC3. It is a primary study as it details specific procedures and results, satisfying IC4. The article does not violate any exclusion criteria, as it is written in English, does not address teaching agile methods, does not fail to address agile methodologies, and is not a tertiary or meta-analysis study. It also answers the research question on the economic response of stocking rates and summer maize feeding rates, meeting IC9.

TITLE: Agile and Kanban in Coordination
ABSTRACT: Iterative development and Kanban are not mutually exclusive competing methodologies, in essence they are complementary processes that when used together can facilitate higher performance in large development teams. This paper is a walkthrough of the Network Gaming team's implementation of Iterative Agile alongside Lean Kanban here at WMS Gaming. The intent is to cover the processes created and the improvements achieved with this coordinated Agile / Lean system.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is written in English (EC1 not violated), addresses software project requirements in the context of agile and Kanban methodologies (IC1 satisfied), is based on a real-world industry implementation (IC2 satisfied), and describes a qualitative study of processes and improvements (IC3 and IC4 satisfied). No exclusion criteria are violated, and all inclusion criteria are met.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), it is from academia (IC2), it can be considered qualitative research as it discusses processes and improvements (IC3), and it is a primary study since it provides a walkthrough of a specific team's implementation (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria.

TITLE: A Starting Point for Negotiations—Delivering with a Heterogeneous Team
ABSTRACT: This paper presents a counterintuitive Pre-Sprint Work Balancing methodology that has substantially increased the ability of our highly heterogeneous Scrum [1] team to deliver what it promises at the end of each sprint. The process essentially consists of preplanning steps that acknowledge both the heterogeneity in developer's time and skill level, as well as Product Owner priorities. These preplanning activities act as a starting point for negotiations with the team during the Sprint Planning Meeting. For our team, delivery of all promised tasks in a sprint has increased from less than 1/3 of our sprints to more than 2/3, with indications that we are heading towards nearly 100% delivery.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software project requirements in an agile context (Scrum), specifically focusing on improving delivery rates in a heterogeneous team. It is written in English, is a primary study (describes a practical methodology developed and tested in a real team), and does not violate any exclusion criteria. It does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), is not incomplete or a draft (EC4), and addresses at least one agile methodology (Scrum, EC7). All inclusion criteria are met.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies, specifically Scrum. It is from an industry perspective, as it discusses a practical application within a team. The research is not explicitly stated as qualitative or quantitative, but it does provide empirical evidence of increased sprint delivery rates, which leans towards quantitative research. It is a primary study, being an original work presenting findings from actual practice. The article does not violate any exclusion criteria as it is written in English, is not a draft or just an abstract, does not deal with teaching agile methods, and does not fail to address agile methodologies or research questions.

TITLE: A tool for incorporating unit testing into a Java programming curriculum
ABSTRACT: In the development of object-oriented programming courses, an often overlooking but important area is testing. Generally, testing is formally introduced in software engineering courses and may not form part of the practical aspects of a programming course. As a result, this concept can play a de-emphasized role during the presentation of the course material. To counteract this problem, the HF2 (Highly Extendable and Flexible) unit testing framework was created. Its primary focus is the incorporation of unit testing into an object-oriented programming curriculum. HF2 provides students with the opportunity to develop and practice testing skills in a structured manner. This paper discusses the structure of the framework and the experiences gained when used in a university environment.
EXPLAIN_A: The study does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies (violates EC3). Instead, it focuses on incorporating unit testing into a programming curriculum, which is educational and not related to software project requirements or agile practices. Additionally, it does not address any agile methodology, violating EC7.
EXPLAIN_B: The article meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies, is from academia, qualitative in nature, and a primary study. It does not violate any exclusion criteria, thus the article is included.

Manufacturers of GaAs wafers are not restricted to supplying electronic device companies. Many of these wafer suppliers are also active in the optoelectronics business. This market sector is comparable in size to that of the electronics sector but is almost exclusively based on discrete devices rather than integrated circuits (ICs). In terms of geography, the key players in the wafer business are located in the three main regions: Europe, Japan, and North America. TITLE: Dynamic provisioning in multi-tenant service clouds
ABSTRACT: Cloud-based systems promise an on-demand service provisioning system along with a “pay-as-you-use” policy. In the case of multi-tenant systems this would mean dynamic creation of a tenant by integrating existing cloud-based services on the fly. Presently, dynamic creation of a tenant is handled by building the required components from scratch. Although multi-tenant systems help providers save cost by allocating multiple tenants to the same instance of an application, they incur huge reconfiguration costs. Cost and time spent on these reconfiguration activities can be reduced by re-constructing tenants from existing tenant configurations supported by service providers. Multi-tenant cloud-based systems also lack the facility of allowing clients to specify their requirements. Giving clients the flexibility to specify requirements helps them avoid spending an excessive amount of time and effort looking through a list of services, many of which might not be relevant to them. Moreover, dynamic provisioning in the cloud requires an integrated solution across the technology stack (software, platform and infrastructure) combining functional, non-functional and resource allocation requirements. Existing research works in the area of web service matching, although numerous, still fall short, since they usually consider each requirement type in isolation and cannot provide an integrated solution. To that end, in this paper we investigate the features needed for dynamic service provisioning on the cloud. We propose a novel User Interface-Tenant Selector-Customizer (UTC) model and approach, which enables cloud-based services to be systematically modeled and provisioned as variants of existing service tenants in the cloud. Our approach considers functional, non-functional and resource allocation requirements, which are explicitly specified by the client via the user interface component of the model. To the best of our knowledge, ours is the first such integrated approach. We illustrate our ideas using a realistic running example, and also present a proof-of-concept prototype built using IBM’s Rational Software Architect modeling tool. We also present experimental results demonstrating the applicability of our matching algorithm. Our results show significant reduction in matching time with the help of an elimination process that reduces the search space needed for performing matching.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It focuses on dynamic provisioning in multi-tenant cloud systems and discusses functional, non-functional, and resource allocation requirements, but there is no mention or analysis of agile software development practices, processes, or methodologies. Therefore, it violates Exclusion Criterion EC3: 'the study does not address software requirements' in the context of agile methodologies.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is a study from academia (not specified but generally considered part of academic research), and it seems to be a qualitative research (though not explicitly stated, the focus on systematic modeling and provisioning suggests a qualitative approach). It does not explicitly violate any Exclusion Criteria: the language is English (no EC1 violation), it does not focus on software requirements alone but rather integrates them (not EC3), it is not described as incomplete or a draft (no EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (no EC5), it does not deal with teaching agile methods (no EC6), it does not fail to address agile methodologies as it proposes a model for dynamic provisioning (no EC7), and it appears to answer a research question about dynamic provisioning in cloud-based services (no EC9). Therefore, the article meets all Inclusion Criteria.

TITLE: An approach to applying SOFL for agile process and its application in developing a test support tool
ABSTRACT: Structured Object-Oriented Formal Language (SOFL) is a representative formal engineering method for software development. It offers a three-step specification approach to constructing formal specifications, and specification-based inspection and testing for verification and validation. In this paper, we describe a novel approach to applying the SOFL method to achieve agile development process. This approach results from our experience in several collaboration projects with industry, and aims to strike a balance between the fast delivery of software product and the assurance of its quality. We have tested the approach in developing a prototype test support tool.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in an agile development context using SOFL, a formal method, and describes a practical approach applied in industry. It is a primary study that presents a novel application of a formal method to agile processes, satisfies IC1 (software requirements in agile projects), IC2 (industry-based study), IC3 (qualitative/empirical approach), and IC4 (primary study). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses a specific agile methodology (implied by agile process integration) (EC7), and answers a clear research question (EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses software requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is from industry collaboration projects (IC2), and describes a primary study of applying SOFL in agile process development (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria as it is not in a language other than English, is not a draft, presentation slides, or abstract, does not deal with teaching agile methods, addresses agile methodology (SOFL), and answers the research question of applying SOFL for agile development process (EC9).

TITLE: Marriott's Agile Turnaround
ABSTRACT: When Marriott began to build its brand management intranet, the tech vendor ran into several problems that jeopardized the whole program. The introduction of Agile began a long recovery process: When should you be covert/overt with Agile practices? How do you convince stakeholders a daily concall is more efficient than a weekly concall? Why would you pay for the tech vendorpsilas Agile training? How do you structure Firm Fixed pricing to be Agile? This is the story of how applying Agile techniques, first covertly, then out in the open, slowly steered the ship on course.

The article does not violate any Exclusion Criteria as it's written in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is complete (no indication of being a draft, slides, or abstract - EC4), it's not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (EC7), and seems to answer research questions related to Agile practices (EC9).

TITLE: Herding Cats: Managing Large Test Suites
ABSTRACT: This is the story of staying green in the midst of the challenges we faced as we accumulated an increasing number of automated tests. Iowa Student Loan (ISL) is well beyond the adoption phase of agile. Our commitment to writing tests has resulted in an enormous set of tests. We faced many challenges in keeping our tests under control. A few of the challenges that surfaced include: overly coupled tests, volatile dependencies and turned off tests. It took a lot of energy, discipline, and resources to overcome these challenges. We would like to share the techniques and experiences that emerged as we struggled to stay on green bar.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is a case study that describes challenges in managing large test suites but does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. TITLE: Communication and co-ordination practices in software engineering projects
ABSTRACT: In this paper we report on the investigation, description and analysis of communication and co-ordination practices in software engineering projects. We argue that existing models of the software process do not adequately address the situated, day-to-day practices in which software engineers collectively engage, yet it is through these practices that effective co-ordination is achieved. Drawing on concepts from organizational theory, we describe an approach for studying co-ordination activity in software engineering and the application of this approach to two real-world software projects. We describe key co-ordination issues in these projects and discuss their implications for software engineering practice.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements as per EC3. While it discusses communication and coordination practices in software engineering projects, it does not focus on requirements in software projects using agile methodologies, which is a key requirement for inclusion (IC1). Therefore, it violates Exclusion Criterion EC3 and is classified as EXCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), as it discusses communication and coordination practices within such projects. The study is based on real-world software projects, which can be considered primary research (IC4). The language is English (no violation of EC1), and it does not appear to be a draft, presentation slides, or just an abstract (no violation of EC4). It is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (no violation of EC5) and does not explicitly deal with teaching agile methods or fail to address any agile methodology (no violation of EC6 and EC7). The article seems to answer research questions related to co-ordination issues in software engineering practice (no violation of EC9). Therefore, the article meets all the Inclusion Criteria.

TITLE: Adapting Agile Methodology to Overcome Social Differences in Project Members
ABSTRACT: Projects often consist with members with different values that may cause conflicts within the team causing decrease in members' motivation, involvement, and cohesiveness. In our experiences with off shoring Japanese software development projects to China, we were having difficulties with low quality deliverables and high turnover rate of Chinese members because of social differences. Our attempts to create a common culture were not very successful because people in general are less likely to change their basic views and behavior in a short period of time. We, however, were able to obtain success by acknowledging that differences are going to exist and adopting and adapting agile practices in consideration of the existence of these differences. We will show Kaizen as is used by a Japanese company in software development. We will focus on our experiences with social differences we've found and how we continuously adapted practices in our project to take better advantage of the situation as relationship between members changed. It is based on our over 10 years of experience in trying to improve a software package development at a software company in China, which has now become our subsidiary. During our attempts, we have learned the importance of agile mentality in resolving value difference issues. We believe what we've learned in adapting agile practices is not just limited to our particular project but can be useful in agile projects in general and thus can be used to assist resolve value differences in organizations as well.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is written in English (IC1), addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), and focuses on adapting agile practices to overcome social differences in team members, which aligns with agile principles. It is based on real-world industry experience (IC2), uses qualitative research methods (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). TITLE: Extreme programming of multi-agent systems
ABSTRACT: The complexity of communication scenarios between agents make multi-agent systems difficult to build. Most of the existing Agent-Oriented Software Engineering methodologies face this complexity by guiding the developers through a rather waterfall-based process with a series of intermediate modeling artifacts. While these methodologies lead to executable prototypes relatively late and are expensive when requirements change, we explore a rather evolutionary approach with explicit support for change and rapid feedback. In particular, we apply Extreme Programming, a modern agile methodology from object-oriented software technology, for the design and implementation of multi-agent systems. The only modeling artifacts that are being maintained in our approach are a process model with which domain experts and developers design and communicate agent application scenarios, and the executable agent source code including automated test cases. We have successfully applied our approach for the development of a prototypical multi-agent system for clinical information logistics.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in multi-agent systems using Extreme Programming, an agile methodology. It is a primary study that applies an agile approach to a software development context, not focused on teaching agile methods or tertiary research. The study is written in English, is complete and not a draft or abstract, and addresses at least one agile methodology (Extreme Programming). It satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies, specifically applying Extreme Programming to multi-agent systems. It is a study from academia (as it discusses a prototype development), and it is qualitative in nature, discussing the process and application of a methodology. It is a primary study, not a secondary or meta-analysis, and it does not violate any exclusion criteria.

TITLE: Management Information System Requirements Analysis Model Based on the Agile Development
ABSTRACT: The success rate is low in China, the main reason is the variability and uncertainty of requirements during investigation analysis. Requirements analysis has a pivotal role in the process of system development, so it is necessary to do a deep study on it. In order to deal with the rapidly changing system requirements, the essay signify the uncertainty, disagreement, priority of every requirement with numerical quantization within the 3D-model, based on agile project management thought, using the incremental iteration method to gradually clear system requirements. The model is convenient to decompose, refine, and specific every requirement, and is helpful for developers to make a more comprehensive and clear understanding. It is conducive for developers better understand requirements change trend, and have a good control of main change reasons, which effectively improves the success rate of system development.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in the context of agile development, specifically focusing on a model that quantizes requirement uncertainty, disagreement, and priority using an incremental iteration method. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (incremental iteration) (EC7), and answers at least one research question (improving success rate of system development) (EC9). It meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is a study (academic context) (IC2), is qualitative in nature (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses management information system requirements analysis in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is likely from academia given its nature (IC2), seems to be a qualitative study based on its abstract (IC3), and presents a primary study model (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria, as it is written in English, does not address software requirements in a generic sense but specifically focuses on requirements analysis within agile development, is presumably complete and not just a draft, presentation slides, or an abstract, is not tertiary or a meta-analysis, does not deal with teaching agile methods but applies agile methodology, addresses agile methodology (contrary to EC7), and seems to answer the research question on improving the success rate of system development.

TITLE: A study to support agile methods more effectively through traceability
ABSTRACT: Traceability is recognized to be important for supporting agile development processes. However, after analyzing many of the existing traceability approaches it can be concluded that they strongly depend on traditional development process characteristics. Within this paper it is justified that this is a drawback to support adequately agile processes. As it is discussed, some concepts do not have the same semantics for traditional and agile methodologies. This paper proposes three features that traceability models should support to be less dependent on a specific development process: (1) user-definable traceability links, (2) roles, and (3) linkage rules. To present how these features can be applied, an emerging traceability metamodel (TmM) will be used within this paper. TmM supports the definition of traceability methodologies adapted to the needs of each project. As it is shown, after introducing these three features into traceability models, two main advantages are obtained: 1) the support they can provide to agile process stakeholders is significantly more extensive, and 2) it will be possible to achieve a higher degree of automation. In this sense it will be feasible to have a methodical trace acquisition and maintenance process adapted to agile processes.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile development processes by proposing traceability features tailored to agile methodologies. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (EC7), and answers at least one research question (EC9). It meets all inclusion criteria: it focuses on requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is a research study (IC2), employs a qualitative approach (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article does not violate any Exclusion Criteria: EC1: The article is written in English. EC3: The article addresses software requirements by discussing traceability in agile development processes. EC4: The article is a full study, not a draft or abstract. EC5: The study is not a tertiary source or meta-analysis. EC6: The article does not specifically deal with teaching agile methods. EC7: The study does not fail to address any agile methodology; instead, it discusses traceability in the context of agile processes. EC9: The article answers the research question of supporting agile methods more effectively through traceability. The article meets all Inclusion Criteria: IC1: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies by discussing traceability. -

TITLE: Best practices for integrating user-centered design and agile software development
ABSTRACT: Agile Methods have a distinct culture that at a first glance seems to conflict with User-Centered Design. However, the use of agile methods can result in improved usability of software systems. This tutorial aims to present and discuss the best practices regarding the integration of User-Centered Design and Agile Methods. We believe that the lessons learned from this tutorial can be really useful and applicable in both industry and academic contexts.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is a tutorial that presents best practices for integrating user-centered design and agile methods, but it does not describe a study that addresses software requirements or answer any research questions. Additionally, it is not a primary or secondary study as it lacks empirical research components, thus failing IC4.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is relevant to both industry and academia (IC2), and discusses integration practices, which can be considered qualitative research (IC3). It is a primary study (IC4) and does not violate any exclusion criteria (EC1-EC9).

TITLE: User Experience Design Goes Agile in Lean Transformation—A Case Study
ABSTRACT: This paper describes the results of a single-case case study, exploring the role of user experience (UX) work in agile software development. The case study company is a large multinational telecommunication company undergoing a lean transformation process. In this case, lean transformation includes the adoption of agile software development practices. Transformation to agile practices had taken place one year prior to the analysis. The analysis is based on documentation analysis and semi-structured interviews of seven software development professionals. The results show that there were difficulties integrating UX design and software engineering work in an agile and iterative manner. The transition process succeeded in shifting UX and related documentation to a central planning role. The roles of the UX designers in the teams were still under re-definition. There was also a clear need to establish new ways of collaboration between UX professionals and software designers.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile methodologies (IC1), is based on a case study from industry (IC2), uses qualitative research methods (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software development practices (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (agile software development) (EC7), and answers at least one research question (e.g., integration challenges of UX in agile) (EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1). It is a case study from industry (IC2). Although the methodology of research is qualitative (IC3), it is a primary study, not secondary or tertiary (IC4). The article does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is written in English (EC1), it does not solely focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), it does not fail to address an agile methodology but rather discusses the integration of UX in agile practices (EC7), it does not appear to be incomplete, a draft, or just an abstract (EC4), it is not a meta-analysis (EC5), and it does not fail to answer the research question as it provides insights into the integration of UX in agile practices (EC9).

TITLE: Agile software development and its compatibility with a document-driven approach? A case study
ABSTRACT: It is generally assumed among software developers and managers that a document-driven development process is incompatible with an agile development process. There are few reports on this issue and even less empirical research documenting the assumed incompatibility. More and more software companies however have a desire to adopt agile development processes while maintaining compliance with a quality assurance standard or even a process standard. We have studied the software development process of a Danish pharmaceutical company. For market reasons the company has to comply the US Food and Drug Administration's standards for software development. The company has also successfully implemented significant parts of the agile methodology Scrum. We describe this case and we analyse using Soft Systems Methodology how well the development process combines these diverging sets of process requirements. We find that despite much effort the agile development process suffers from its adaptation to the FDA standard, but at the same time many of the genuine qualities of an agile process have been maintained. From this case study we discuss the implications for development companies facing the challenge of implementing a mixed development approach. Â© 2009 Heeager & Nielsen.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile development processes (IC1), specifically examining the compatibility between agile methodologies (Scrum) and document-driven, regulatory-compliant development (FDA standards). It is a case study conducted in an industry setting (IC2), uses qualitative research methods (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is not incomplete or a draft (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (Scrum, EC7), and answers at least one research question (compatibility of agile with regulatory standards, EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article meets all Inclusion Criteria: it addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it is a study from a Danish pharmaceutical company, which can be considered academic or industry research (IC2), the study uses Soft Systems Methodology which can be considered a qualitative research approach (IC3), and it is a primary study, not a secondary one (IC4). Additionally, the article does not violate any Exclusion Criteria: it is written in English (EC1), it does not fail to address software requirements but specifically discusses the compatibility of a document-driven development process with an agile process (EC3), it is not incomplete or a draft (EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not solely focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), it addresses the compatibility of agile methods with another process requirement, which is a genuine agile quality (EC7), and it

TITLE: NORMATIC: A visual tool for modeling Non-Functional Requirements in agile processes
ABSTRACT: There is consensus in the research community that agile software development methodologies, such as Scrum, are becoming more and more popular in delivering quality Functional Requirements (FRs). However, agile methodologies have not adequately modeled Non-Functional Requirements (NFRs) and their potential solutions (operationalizations) with FRs in early development phases-let alone having tools to support such initiatives. This research proposes NORMATIC, a Java-based simulation tool for modeling non-functional requirements for semi-automatic agile processes. NORMATIC is the semi-automatic tool that supports the more general Non-Functional Requirements Modeling for Agile Processes (NORMAP) Methodology. Early results show that the tool can potentially help agile software development teams in reasoning about and visually modeling NFRs as first-class artifacts early on during requirements gathering and analysis phases. The tool can also aid project managers and Scrum teams in user story estimate and risk calculations as well as risk-driven planning and visualization of the proposed plans.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is written in English, addresses software requirements in agile methodologies (specifically non-functional requirements), and proposes a tool (NORMATIC) to support modeling of NFRs in agile processes. It is a primary study that provides a detailed research proposal with early results, not a draft, abstract, or tertiary study. It meets all inclusion criteria (IC1, IC2, IC3, IC4) and violates no exclusion criteria (EC1, EC3, EC4, EC5, EC6, EC7, EC9). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article is written in English (IC1 criterion met). It addresses Non-Functional Requirements in software projects using agile methodologies, specifically mentioning Scrum (IC1 criterion met). The study is likely from academia, given its research proposal and potential implications for agile software development teams (IC2 criterion met). Although the research type is not explicitly stated as qualitative or quantitative, the use of a Java-based simulation tool suggests a quantitative approach to modeling and testing (IC3 criterion met). The study seems to be a primary research project, as it proposes and tests a new tool, NORMATIC, without relying on secondary data (IC4 criterion met). There is no evidence of the article violating any exclusion criteria: It is not written in a language other than English

TITLE: A case study of customer communication in globally distributed software product development
ABSTRACT: Agile methodologies emphasize the importance of customer and highlight that communication with the customer is seen as a central tenet. Despite the prevalence and benefits associated with globally distributed software development, communication can be much more challenging in such environments due to temporal, geographical and cultural distances. This paper describes results from a case study of customer communication in a globally distributed product development program applying both traditional and agile approaches. Based on the study, the frequency of communication, the content of that communication and engagement with the customer along with a support for rapid decision making among the development teams and the customer groups are important success factors in distributed agile development.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in the context of agile methodologies within globally distributed software development. It describes a case study (primary research) that examines customer communication, a key aspect of agile practices, and identifies success factors related to communication in distributed environments. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software project requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (implied by the context of agile approaches) (EC7), and responds to research questions about communication and engagement (EC9). It meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is a primary study from industry or academia (likely industry given the context), is qualitative (case study) (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4).
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it's a study from academia (which can be inferred from being a case study, satisfying IC2), the nature of the research seems qualitative as it discusses the results of a case study (IC3), and it's a primary study (IC4). The article does not violate any of the exclusion criteria (EC1-EC9).

TITLE: Runtime verification for multicore SoC with high-quality trace data

TITLE: Agile Project Management: A Case Study of a Virtual Research Environment Development Project
ABSTRACT: In this paper we use a case study of a project to create a Web 2.0-based, Virtual Research Environment (VRE) for researchers to share digital resources in order to reflect on the principles and practices for embedding eResearch applications within user communities. In particular, we focus on the software development methodologies and project management techniques adopted by the project team in order to ensure that the project remained responsive to changing user requirements without compromising their capacity to keep the project ‘on track’, i.e. meeting the goals declared in the project proposal within budget and on time. Drawing on ethnographic fieldwork, we describe how the project team, whose members are distributed across multiple sites (and often mobile), exploit a repertoire of coordination mechanisms, communication modes and tools, artefacts and structuring devices as they seek to establish the orderly running of the project while following an agile, user-centred development approach.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is written in English (meets EC1), addresses software requirements in the context of agile methodologies (meets IC1), focuses on a real-world project in industry (meets IC2), uses qualitative research methods through ethnographic fieldwork (meets IC3), and is a primary study (meets IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is not a draft, abstract, or tertiary study (EC4, EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (implied by the focus on agile, user-centred development), and answers relevant research questions about project management practices in agile environments (meets EC9). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is a study from academia (IC2), and it qualitatively describes the software development methodologies and project management techniques (IC3). It is a primary study (IC4), and it does not violate any exclusion criteria. It does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6) and does not fail to address an agile methodology (EC7). It addresses the research question about the application of agile principles and practices in the development of a VRE (EC9).

TITLE: Architectural decision modeling with reuse: challenges and opportunities
ABSTRACT: Architectural decision modeling aims at supporting the software architecture design process by capturing a reusable body of architectural knowledge. Whereas significant progress has been made towards this vision, there still remains a number of open problems. This paper outlines selected research challenges and opportunities related to knowledge capturing and sharing, model evolution and verification, and the integration of the architectural design process with existing software development methodologies. Our goal is to start a discussion on a roadmap for future research on reusable modeling of architectural decisions.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is a review paper that outlines research challenges and opportunities in architectural decision modeling without presenting specific software requirements or addressing at least one agile methodology. It fails to address software requirements (EC3) and does not provide empirical or practical insights into agile software development processes, thus violating Exclusion Criterion EC3 and not satisfying Inclusion Criterion IC1.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), as it discusses architectural decision modeling which is a part of the software architecture design process. It is a primary study (IC4) that outlines research challenges and opportunities, making it relevant to the field. The article is written in English and does not appear to deal with teaching methods or fail to address any agile methodology, satisfying all the inclusion criteria.

TITLE: Introducing the QCEP-testing system for executable acceptance test driven development of complex event processing applications
ABSTRACT: In this paper we introduce the open source testing system QCEP-TS for realizing executable acceptance test driven development (EATDD) of complex event processing (CEP) applications. We will motivate the need of EATDD in this domain and argue that state ...

TITLE: Requirements change management according to modified Scrum process [Upravljanje izmenama zahteva u skladu sa modifikovanim Scrum procesom]
ABSTRACT: In this paper the influence of change requirements during several agile software projects is examined. Consequences that change requirements have had on projects are analyzed. Also some possible ways of successful management of these consequences are suggested. Therefore, modified Scrum process that involve activities for successful requirements change management during project is proposed. Â© 2012 IEEE.

TITLE: Agile processes and modeling
ABSTRACT: The new wave of agile and iterative processes, including Extreme Programming, the Unified Process, Scrum, and others represent the fruition of 30 years of investigation and encouragement to build software not according to the flawed "waterfall" model of three major phases of requirements -> design -> construct, but rather, in short (2-6 week) time boxed steps or iterations. In this keynote presentation, I summarize project research illustrating the failure of the "waterfall" and explore the motivation for iterative processes. Then I examine the key values of the Agile Manifesto: â€¢ Individuals and interactions over processes and tools â€¢ Working software over comprehensive documentation â€¢ Customer collaboration over contract negotiation â€¢ Responding to change over following a plan This is followed by a summary of the key ideas in XP, Scrum, UP, and DSDM. The keynote closes with a look at the practice of agile modeling that includes low-fidelity modeling with a preference to using simple tools such as paper and whiteboards, modeling in pairs, and parallel model building. Â© Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2003.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is a keynote presentation summarizing agile processes and modeling, which falls under EC4 (the study is incomplete, a draft, presentation slides, or just an abstract). It does not present a primary or secondary study that addresses software requirements in a research context, thus failing to meet the inclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), as it discusses the failure of the 'waterfall' model and the motivation for iterative processes, specifically in software development. It is a keynote presentation that could originate from academia or industry (IC2), likely qualitative based on its descriptive nature (IC3). Although it's a presentation, it does not explicitly state if it's primary or secondary research (IC4), but given its summarizing and illustrative nature, it's reasonable to infer it's primary. The article does not violate any of the exclusion criteria (EC1-EC9).

TITLE: Incorporating Security Requirements Engineering into the Dynamic Systems Development Method
ABSTRACT: This paper provides a roadmap for addressing security requirements on projects using an agile approach. The Dynamic Systems Development Method (DSDM) is used as an example framework for development. Security quality requirements engineering (SQUARE) is used as an example methodology to address security issues early in the development life cycle. SQUARE can be more effective when it fits into an organization's existing development process. Hence this paper describes a way to fit the SQUARE methodology into the DSDM framework.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile projects by integrating security requirements engineering (SQUARE) into the DSDM framework, which is an agile methodology. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (DSDM) (EC7), and answers a clear research question about integrating security requirements into agile development (EC9). It meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is a research study (academic context) (IC2), and presents a methodological approach (qualitative/analytical) (IC3 and IC4). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses security requirements engineering within software projects using an agile methodology (DSDM), satisfying IC1. It is written in English and is a study from academia, meeting IC2 and IC3. The paper provides a primary study as described, aligning with IC4. It does not violate any exclusion criteria, making it eligible for inclusion.

TITLE: Issues and mitigation strategies when using agile industrial software development processes in student software engineering projects
ABSTRACT: In computer science education, one of the main goals for educators is to prepare the student for employment in an industrial environment. For this it is required that the students are familiar with the major development process, ideally on the example of a concrete student project. During a one-semester software development seminar the students were grouped into 7 groups with 4-5 students each and each group was assigned eXtreme Programming, SCRUM or Open Unified Process as development process. Each student was asked to keep a development diary and answer questionnaires during and at the end of the project. Each group was asked to document the changes to their development process, identified development problems, employed mitigation strategies and the project progress in form of a retrospective report. Analysis of the reports revealed common issues and mitigation strategies, which can be classified into the following: meeting organization; communication; project roles, requirements engineering, continuous tests and process adherence. The employed mitigation strategies were classified into the same categories; quantified and evaluated regarding their respective effectiveness.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is based on a study conducted in an academic setting (IC2), employs qualitative research through analysis of student reports and retrospectives (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software development processes (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (XP, SCRUM, Open Unified Process) (EC7), and answers research questions regarding issues and mitigation strategies (EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article meets all Inclusion Criteria: it addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it is a study from academia (IC2), it is qualitative research as indicated by the use of development diaries and questionnaires (IC3), and it is a primary study since it involves student projects and direct analysis of retrospective reports (IC4). It does not violate any Exclusion Criteria: it is written in English (EC1), it does not fail to address at least one agile methodology as it discusses eXtreme Programming, SCRUM, and Open Unified Process (EC7), it is not incomplete, a draft, presentation slides, or just an abstract (EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not solely focus on teaching agile methods but rather on the application of agile methodologies in student projects (EC6), and it does not fail to answer at least one research question as it analyzes common issues and mitigation strategies (EC9).

TITLE: Domain specific feature modeling for software product lines
ABSTRACT: This paper summarizes our experience with introducing feature modeling into a product line for imaging and therapy systems in the Siemens Healthcare Sector. Determining and negotiating the scope in a product line that spans several business units with their own economic goals is challenging. Feature modeling offers a good way to do variability/commonality analysis for complex product lines. A precondition for feature modeling is the identification of all features supporting the product line. To identify these features, we developed a method for systematically deriving a feature model top down based on domain know-how. We call this method domain specific feature modeling. As the primary artifact to describe the problem space, a domain specific feature model additionally improves the requirement understanding for all stakeholders by considerably improving the scoping, traceability, testing, efficiency and transparency of planning activities and making the development efforts easier to estimate. In this paper, we share our experience with domain specific feature modeling in a large platform project and describe the lessons learned. We describe our general approach that can also be used for other domains.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It focuses on feature modeling in a product line setting, which is related to software product lines but does not involve agile methods or their application in requirement management. Therefore, it violates Exclusion Criterion EC7 (does not address at least one agile methodology) and is classified as EXCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article satisfies all Inclusion Criteria: it addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is a study from industry (IC2), and it is a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any Exclusion Criteria: the article is written in English (EC1), it does not fail to address any agile methodologies (EC7), and it does not fail to answer any research questions (EC9).

TITLE: A tool for supporting feature-driven development
ABSTRACT: This paper deals with the Featured Driven Development (FDD), an agile software development method. According to the requirement analysis for the FDD method application, an information system has been created providing all team members with instruments to follow the method. This tool has been implemented as a multi-user web-based application enabling creation of feature lists, planning a project, supporting cooperation among members of a feature-team, and tracking project progress in an illustrative way. To support project management and communication with customer representatives, a wide range of reporting features has been provided. Â© 2008 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in the context of Feature-Driven Development (FDD), an agile methodology, by describing a tool that supports feature planning, team collaboration, and project tracking. It is a primary study (a developed tool implemented in a real-world setting) and written in English. It does not violate any exclusion criteria (EC1, EC3, EC4, EC5, EC6, EC7, EC9), as it directly addresses an agile methodology, is not a tertiary or meta-analysis, is not focused on teaching agile methods, and answers a clear research question related to supporting FDD. It meets all inclusion criteria: IC1 (software requirements in agile context), IC2 (industry or academic context—likely academic), IC3 (qualitative/quantitative—implied by implementation and evaluation), and IC4 (primary study).

TITLE: An approach to test-driven development of conceptual schemas
ABSTRACT: Test-Driven Development (TDD) is an extreme programming development method in which a software system is developed in short iterations. In this paper we present the Test-Driven Conceptual Modeling (TDCM) method, which is an application of \{TDD\} for conceptual modeling, and we show how to develop a conceptual schema using it. In TDCM, a system's conceptual schema is incrementally obtained by performing three kinds of tasks: (1) Write a test the system should pass; (2) Change the schema to pass the test; and (3) Refactor the schema to improve its qualities. We also describe an integration approach of \{TDCM\} into a broad set of software development methodologies, including the Unified Process development methodology, the MDD-based approaches, the storytest-driven agile methods and the goal and scenario-oriented requirements engineering methods. We deal with schemas written in UML/OCL, but the \{TDCM\} method could be adapted to the development of schemas in other languages.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements as it focuses on conceptual modeling and test-driven development of schemas, not software project requirements. It fails to address at least one agile methodology as it only mentions integration into a broad set of methodologies without detailing how it applies to agile practices. This violates EC3 and EC7.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), specifically the Test-Driven Development method within the conceptual modeling context (TDCM) (IC1). It is a study from academia, as it presents a methodological approach to conceptual schema development (IC2). The article, as an abstract and a description of a method, likely includes qualitative aspects of the research process (IC3). It is not a primary study but rather a description of a method (IC4). The article does not seem to violate any exclusion criteria, as it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is not incomplete or a draft (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses the conceptual modeling aspect of agile methodologies (EC7), and it is assumed to address research questions related to TDCM (EC9).

TITLE: Software quality and agile methods
ABSTRACT: Agile methods may produce software faster but we also need to know how they meet our quality requirements. In this paper we compare the waterfall model with agile processes to show how agile methods achieve software quality under time pressure and in an unstable requirements environment, i.e. we analyze agile software quality assurance. We present a detailed waterfall model showing its software quality support processes. We then show the quality practices that agile methods have integrated into their processes. This allows us to answer the question "Can agile methods ensure quality even though they develop software faster and can handle unstable requirements?" Â© 2004 IEEE.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software quality in the context of agile methodologies, comparing them with the waterfall model to analyze how agile methods achieve quality under time pressure and unstable requirements. It meets IC1 (addresses software quality in agile projects), IC2 (academic study), IC3 (qualitative analysis), and IC4 (primary study). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (e.g., general agile practices), and answers a research question (EC9). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it's a study from academia (IC2), it's a qualitative study based on comparison and analysis (IC3), and it's a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any of the exclusion criteria.

TITLE: Authorisation Requirements on a Budget
ABSTRACT: Engineering information system deployment is squeezed by a shrinking commitment to requirements definition and an expanding need to determine the security requirements of such systems. This paper examines the causes and effects of this squeeze. Commitment is shrinking because of past requirements experiences, misunderstood trends in system development and requirements fatigue, while needs are expanding because of recent emphasis on Internet access to data, online transactions and workflow, which greatly increase the severity of the authorisation problem. Some approaches to quantifying and addressing this problem are introduced.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It focuses on authorisation requirements in engineering information systems, discussing security and commitment issues, but fails to address at least one agile methodology (IC7) and does not explicitly relate to agile software development practices. Therefore, it violates Exclusion Criterion EC7 and does not meet Inclusion Criterion IC1.
EXPLAIN_B: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies, which is a requirement under IC1. It is also a qualitative study examining causes and effects, which does not satisfy the quantitative requirement under IC3. Furthermore, it does not directly discuss agile methodologies or answer specific research questions related to them, violating EC7 and EC9.

TITLE: Evidence Management for Evolutionary Safety Assurance and Certification
ABSTRACT: Safety assurance and certification are amongst the most expensive and time-consuming activities in the development of safety-critical systems. Deeming a system to be safe involves gathering convincing evidence to argue the safe operation of the system, usually according to the requirements of some safety standard. To handle large collections of safety evidence effectively, practitioners need knowledge of how to classify different types of evidence, how to structure the evidence to show fulfilment of standards' requirements, and how to assess the evidence. However, the notion of evidence is vague and safety standards' requirements can be ambiguous and difficult to understand. Major problems also arise when a system evolves, as the body of safety evidence has to be adequately maintained in order to ensure system safety and allow its demonstration. In this context, this PhD aims to propose a framework for safety evidence management in evolutionary scenarios. The thesis work will concentrate on devising a model-based and customizable infrastructure for storage, manipulation, reuse, and analysis of evolving safety evidence. The infrastructure will be developed and evaluated in the scope of OPENCOSS a large-scale European research project.
EXPLAIN_A: The article violates Exclusion Criterion EC7: it fails to address at least one agile methodology. The abstract discusses safety evidence management in evolutionary scenarios and references a research project (OPENCOSS), but there is no mention of any agile methodology or its application in software requirements management. Therefore, it does not meet the inclusion criteria related to agile methodologies and is excluded.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in safety projects using methodologies that are relevant to agile practices, as it discusses managing safety evidence in evolving systems. Although it does not explicitly mention agile methodologies, the focus on the management and analysis of evidence aligns with the qualitative research within the safety assurance context, which can be considered a form of industry-based study. The study is not excluded by any of the exclusion criteria and satisfies the inclusion criteria by focusing on the effective handling of safety evidence, which is a key requirement in software projects, even if not explicitly stated as agile methodologies.

TITLE:
Agile Development and User Experience Design Integration as an Ongoing
Achievement in Practice
ABSTRACT: Little is known about how Agile developers and UX designers integrate their work on a day-to-day basis. While accounts in the literature attempt to integrate Agile development and UX design by combining their processes and tools, the contradicting claims found in the accounts complicate extracting advice from such accounts. This paper reports on three ethnographically-informed field studies of the day-today practice of developers and designers in organisational settings. Our results show that integration is achieved in practice through (1) mutual awareness, (2) expectations about acceptable behaviour, (3) negotiating progress and (4) engaging with each other. Successful integration relies on practices that support and maintain these four aspects in the day-to-day work of developers and designers.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software project requirements through the integration of Agile development and UX design, which aligns with IC1. It is based on ethnographic field studies in organizational settings, satisfying IC2. The study is qualitative and conducted in practice, meeting IC3. It is a primary study as it reports original field research, fulfilling IC4. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching Agile (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (Agile development) (EC7), and answers research questions about daily integration practices (EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The reason for this classification is that the article clearly addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), as it discusses the integration of Agile development and UX design. Furthermore, the paper is written in English (EC1), and it does not seem to be a draft, presentation slides, or an abstract (EC4). The article appears to be a primary study (IC4) that includes qualitative research (IC3), as it is based on ethnographically-informed field studies. It doesn't fall under any exclusion criteria: it is not written in a language other than English, does not address non-software requirements, is not incomplete, not a tertiary source or a a meta-analysis, does not solely deal with teaching agile methods, includes at least one agile methodology (Agile development and UX design integration), and it does answer the research question about the daily practice of developers and designers.

TITLE: Teaching software engineering: a practical approach
ABSTRACT: In teaching software engineering, it is a major challenge to integrate applied methodology and theory into the practice of software development. Today teaching a course in software engineering involves a theoretical approach with white board and doing ...
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses teaching software engineering and focuses on pedagogical approaches, which falls under EC6 (deals with teaching agile methods). Although it mentions methodology integration, it does not specifically address agile methodologies as required by IC7. Therefore, it violates EC6 and is excluded.
EXPLAIN_B: While the article addresses teaching methods in software engineering, it does not specifically address requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1). Therefore, it fails to meet all Inclusion Criteria.

TITLE: Prototype system for pursuing firm’s core capability
ABSTRACT: Core capabilities are critical abilities that enhance and sustain an organization’s competitive advantage in extremely competitive environments. In today’s complex and dynamic business environment, companies are often prevented from effectively and efficiently evaluating relevant factors necessary for developing their core capability strategic systems. These systems, with inherent human decision-making processes, should be fully considered when creating a method for determining a firm’s suitable or required core capabilities. It is helpful to implement IT-based group decision support systems (GDSS) with soft computing algorithms to assist managers in determining the appropriate core capabilities for the firm. Therefore, this study develops a holistic group decision support system in which similarity measures, fuzzy set theory, and fuzzy mathematics programming are implemented to facilitate managers in making decisions. Through evaluations done in actual cases, we have found that this system creates a flexible and user-friendly environment that aids top management and other relevant staff members in evaluating all relevant factors related to core capabilities.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It focuses on a group decision support system using soft computing algorithms, but there is no mention of agile software development practices, processes, or methodologies. This violates Exclusion Criterion EC3, which requires the study to address software requirements using agile methodologies.
