EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects (IC1) using agile methodologies by developing a group decision support system (GDSS) with soft computing algorithms. It is a study from academia (IC2) and is qualitative in nature (IC3), as it involves the development and evaluation of a system. It is a primary study (IC4) since it discusses the creation and application of the prototype system. The article does not violate any exclusion criteria as it is written in English, addresses a specific aspect of agile methodologies (which are core capabilities), and does not fall into categories such as tertiary research, teaching agile methods, or failing to address agile methodologies (EC1-EC7). The article provides insights into how the system can aid managers in evaluating core capabilities, thus addressing the research questions.

TITLE: An Agile \{MDA\} Approach for Service-Oriented Components
ABSTRACT: Two important principles that drive the agile \{MDA\} processes are immediate execution and test first development. This paper presents a component model, called iComponent, that allows the development of executable models based on agile principles and service orientation. In order to ensure simple and fast definition of component operations, we use a concrete syntax for \{UML\} structured activities and a corresponding \{UML\} profile. The study also includes a mapping of iComponent to some existing service-oriented component frameworks (iPOJO, OSGi, SCA). The proposed platform-independent component model is part of a framework for component definition, validation and composition.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (specifically agile MDA), as it presents a component model (iComponent) aligned with agile principles like immediate execution and test-first development. It is written in English, not a draft or abstract, and does not focus on teaching agile methods or deal with tertiary or meta-analysis. It addresses at least one agile methodology (agile MDA) and includes a clear research contribution with a component model and mapping to existing frameworks. It satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1) and is a study that can be classified as qualitative research (IC3). It also discusses a component model (iComponent) that aligns with agile principles and service orientation, which is relevant to the topic. The study does not appear to violate any exclusion criteria such as being written in a language other than English, not addressing software requirements, being incomplete or a draft, being tertiary or a meta-analysis, teaching agile methods, failing to address at least one agile methodology, or failing to answer at least one research question.

TITLE: Agility vs. stability at a successful start-up: steps to progress amidst chaos and change
ABSTRACT: It is not uncommon for good technical solutions to fail in the marketplace. Equally true, great business opportunities are not always met with appropriate technical solutions. While there can be many causes to such failures, one common problem is the gap between expectations and implementation. Extreme Programming is an excellent delivery methodology for bridging this gap. This paper presents lessons learned from applying Extreme Programming in a start-up environment. In particular, the challenges of meeting and adapting to evolving requirements are presented.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in a start-up environment using Extreme Programming, an agile methodology. It is a primary study based on lessons learned from real-world application, written in English, and does not fall under tertiary or meta-analysis. It does not deal with teaching agile methods or focus on a single missing agile methodology. It satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), appears to be from an academic setting discussing lessons learned (IC2), likely qualitative research based on the narrative (IC3), and presents primary research findings from a start-up environment (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria as it does not mention issues with English language, lacks a focus on software requirements outside of agile methodologies, is not incomplete or merely an abstract, is not a tertiary or meta-analysis, does not teach agile methods, and does not fail to address agile methodologies or research questions.

TITLE: Quantitative release planning in extreme programming
ABSTRACT: Context Extreme Programming (XP) is one of the most popular agile software development methodologies. \{XP\} is defined as a consistent set of values and practices designed to work well together, but lacks practices for project management and especially for supporting the customer role. The customer representative is constantly under pressure and may experience difficulties in foreseeing the adequacy of a release plan. Objective To assist release planning in \{XP\} by structuring the planning problem and providing an optimization model that suggests a suitable release plan. Method We develop an optimization model that generates a release plan taking into account story size, business value, possible precedence relations, themes, and uncertainty in velocity prediction. The running-time feasibility is established through computational tests. In addition, we provide a practical heuristic approach to velocity estimation. Results Computational tests show that problems with up to six themes and 50 stories can be solved exactly. An example provides insight into uncertainties affecting velocity, and indicates that the model can be applied in practice. Conclusion An optimization model can be used in practice to enable the customer representative to take more informed decisions faster. This can help adopting \{XP\} in projects where plan-driven approaches have traditionally been used.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile methodologies (specifically Extreme Programming), is written in English, is a primary quantitative study, and directly tackles a research problem in software project release planning. It does not violate any exclusion criteria (EC1, EC3, EC4, EC5, EC6, EC7, EC9) and satisfies all inclusion criteria (IC1, IC2, IC3, IC4).
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), specifically in the context of Extreme Programming (XP) (IC1). It is a quantitative study (IC3) that provides an optimization model for release planning (IC1). The study appears to be a primary research article, as it describes the development of an optimization model, computational tests, and practical application (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: the article is written in English (EC1), it directly addresses a software requirement (EC3), it is not incomplete or a draft (EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not solely deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), it addresses an agile methodology (XP) by providing an optimization model for release planning (EC7), and it addresses the research question of assisting release planning in XP (EC9).

TITLE: Agile Team Perceptions of Productivity Factors
ABSTRACT: In this paper, we investigate agile team perceptions of factors impacting their productivity. Within this overall goal, we also investigate which productivity concept was adopted by the agile teams studied. We here conducted two case studies in the industry and analyzed data from two projects that we followed for six months. From the perspective of agile team members, the three most perceived factors impacting on their productivity were appropriate team composition and allocation, external dependencies, and staff turnover. Teams also mentioned pair programming and collocation as agile practices that impact productivity. As a secondary finding, most team members did not share the same understanding of the concept of productivity. While some known factors still impact agile team productivity, new factors emerged from the interviews as potential productivity factors impacting agile teams.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software project requirements in the context of agile methodologies (IC1), is based on industry case studies (IC2), uses qualitative research methods (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software project requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (through practices like pair programming and collocation) (EC7), and answers at least one research question (on productivity factors) (EC9).
EXPLAIN_B: The article meets all Inclusion Criteria: it addresses productivity factors in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it is a study from the industry (IC2), it appears to be qualitative research based on the abstract's description of interviews and focus on team perceptions (IC3), and it is a primary study as it followed two projects for six months (IC4). It does not violate any Exclusion Criteria.

TITLE: Avoiding bugs pro-actively by change-oriented programming
ABSTRACT: To minimize the cost of fixing bugs, they need to be identified as soon as possible. Testing the system is a means to detect such defects. However, when all the tests are run, it is often difficult to locate the precise error that causes a test to fail. We propose to use change-oriented programming as a means to detect bugs in a system while it is being developed. Not only may this technique assists in detecting bugs sooner, it can also be used to provide the developer with fine-grained information about the places in the program and test code that relate to the defect. We believe that this will decrease the probability of introducing bugs in a system and speed up the detection of the bugs that do get in.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements as it focuses on bug detection using change-oriented programming rather than requirements in software projects. This violates Exclusion Criterion EC3, which requires the study to address software requirements.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), and it is a study that could potentially be from either industry or academia (IC2). Although the abstract doesn't explicitly state if it is qualitative or quantitative research (IC3), nor does it state if it's a primary or secondary study (IC4), it does not violate any Exclusion Criteria. It is written in English (EC1), it does not seem to be a draft, presentation slides, or just an abstract (EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), it addresses an agile methodology, i.e., change-oriented programming (EC7), and while the research question isn't explicitly stated, it implies an effort to answer questions related to bug detection and prevention (EC9).

TITLE: Integrating UX with scrum in an undergraduate software development project
ABSTRACT: We report our experiences using the Scrum agile software development method in an undergraduate user-centered web development project. Our chief contributions are to report on using Scrum in a summer research setting as distinct from academic-year coursework ...
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in an undergraduate project using the Scrum agile methodology, which satisfies IC1, IC2, and IC4. It is a primary study (firsthand experience report) and not a draft, abstract, meta-analysis, or tertiary study, so it does not violate EC1, EC4, EC5, or EC6. It specifically addresses Scrum, fulfilling IC7. The study is not focused on teaching agile methods (EC6), and it answers the research question about integrating UX with Scrum in a real-world project setting.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is from an academic setting (IC2), and appears to be a study that reports on the application of Scrum, which is an agile methodology (IC3). It is not a draft, presentation slides, or abstract only (EC4), it does not seem to be a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), and it does address Scrum, a specific agile methodology (EC7). The research question seems to be addressed as the article discusses the experiences using Scrum in an undergraduate project (EC9).

TITLE: Potter Model - A Change Compliant Software Development Lifecycle Model
ABSTRACT: A software development life cycle model based on predicting and deciding maximum possible changes which can come in the time line of project completion has been proposed. The model makes it easy for developers to manage the constantly changing requirements and specifications. This model instead of focusing on people and resources focuses on architecture. It is not a replacement for Agile and other iterative models. It is addition of a new perspective of architecture to the existing software development life cycle methodologies.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It proposes a software development lifecycle model focused on architecture and change prediction, without addressing how it integrates with or responds to software requirements in agile environments. This violates Exclusion Criterion EC3, which states that the study must address software requirements.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is based on academic research (assuming it's not explicitly stated but typically such models are developed through research), and discusses a primary study on a new model (IC4). It does not violate Exclusion Criteria: the article is presumably written in English (no language specified), it addresses software requirements (contrary to EC3), it is not incomplete or just an abstract (no information given about draft or slides), it is neither a meta-analysis nor tertiary source (no information provided), it does not solely focus on teaching agile methods but introduces a new model (EC6), it does not explicitly fail to address an agile methodology but rather adds to the existing models (EC7), and it appears to answer the research question of proposing a new model for managing changes in software development (EC9).

TITLE: Software Quality Assurance in XP and Spiral - A Comparative Study
ABSTRACT: Agile processes have been introduced to avoid the problems most of software practitioners have run up against by using traditional software development methodologies. These are well known for their benefits like focus on quality, early business value delivery, higher morale of stakeholders, and the reduced cost/schedule. Also, they can support the earlier and quicker production of the code by dividing the product into small segments called iterations. However, there are on-going debates about their flexibility to accommodate changing requirements and whether the productivity and quality of the agile processes is satisfactory for the customers or not. Previously available studies have mostly focused on comparing XP(eXtreme Programming) with some other agile methodologies, rather than comparing it with traditional plan-driven software development methodologies. In this paper, we identify the XP phases and practices, how they ensure product quality, and map XP phases against the Spiral model phases to prove that XP has built-in QA (quality assurance) practices in its life cycle, in addition to its focus on productivity. A case study is also included to empirically investigate quality of the product developed using XP with comparison to the product developed using Spiral model.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (XP and Spiral), specifically focusing on quality assurance practices. It is a primary study based on a case study that compares XP and the Spiral model, fulfilling IC1, IC2, and IC4. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (XP and Spiral) (EC7), and answers research questions related to quality assurance in both models (EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it's a study from academia (not explicitly industry, but this is not an exclusion criterion), it's a primary study (not a secondary or meta-analysis, EC5), and it's qualitative research (IC3). All exclusion criteria are met: the language is English (no EC1 violation), it doesn't deal with teaching agile methods (no EC6 violation), it doesn't fail to address agile methodologies (no EC7 violation), and it addresses research questions (no EC9 violation).

TITLE: Programmers are from Mars, customers are from Venus: a practical guide for customers on XP projects
ABSTRACT: Extreme Programming and other Agile methods have a dedicated customer role that acts as the interface between development teams and their clients, sponsors, and end-users. The customer is critical to agile projects, but there is little research, experience, or advice about effective practices required to fill that role. We present a set of patterns describing the key roles on a customer team, and the practices that enable customers to fill those roles. By adopting these roles and practices, customers and development teams can increase the velocity and reliability of their projects, and ensure all participants in a project, not just the developers, can work at a sustainable pace.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software project requirements in the context of agile methodologies, specifically Extreme Programming (XP), and provides practical guidance on customer roles and practices. It is not written in a language other than English, is not a draft, abstract, or tertiary study, does not focus on teaching agile methods, and directly addresses at least one agile methodology (XP). It meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria, thus it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1). It presents a practical guide, likely based on industry or academic research (IC2). While the abstract does not specify the research type, it implies the discussion of effective practices, which could be qualitative (IC3). The article seems to present original insights, suggesting it is a primary study (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria, as it is presumably written in English, does not exclude software requirements, is not incomplete, does not deal with teaching agile methods, and does not fail to address agile methodologies or research questions.

TITLE: Software Process and Product Improvement: A Historical Perspective
ABSTRACT: In this paper, a historical overview of significant attempts to get over the software crisis is presented. In particular, we trace the development of lifecycle models and information systems development methodologies during the last four decades. Finally, we explore the role of measurements and outline current and future works leading to process and product improvement.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies (violates EC7). It provides a historical overview of software development lifecycle models and methodologies without focusing on agile practices or requirements management. Therefore, it fails to meet the inclusion criteria, specifically IC1, which requires addressing requirements in software projects using agile methodologies.
EXPLAIN_B: While the article from the given title addresses historical development of software lifecycle models and methodologies, it does not specifically address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies, thus failing to meet IC1. Furthermore, it does not appear to be a study from industry or academia focused on requirements, which is necessary to satisfy IC2, nor does it indicate being qualitative or quantitative research (IC3). Therefore, it does not meet all the Inclusion Criteria.

TITLE: Teaching extreme programming to large groups of students
ABSTRACT: We find the extreme programming methodology highly suitable for introducing undergraduate students to software engineering. To be able to apply this methodology at a reasonable teaching cost for large student groups, we have developed two courses that work in tandem: a team programming course taken by more than 100 students, and a coaching course taken by around 25 students. In this paper we describe our view of how extreme programming fits into the software engineering curriculum, our approach to teaching it, and our experiences, based on two years of running these courses. Particularly important aspects of our set up include team coaching (by older students), fixed working hours, and colocation during development. Our experiences so far are very positive, and we see that students get a good basic understanding of the important concepts in software engineering, rooted in their own practical experience.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses teaching extreme programming to students, which falls under EC6 (deals with teaching agile methods). It does not focus on software requirements or software project requirements in an agile context, thus violating EC6.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is a study from academia (IIC2), and is qualitative research (IC3). It is a primary study (IC4), and it does not violate any exclusion criteria (EC1-EC9). It discusses teaching extreme programming, which is an agile methodology (EC7), thus satisfying the requirement to address at least one agile methodology (EC7). The article answers the research question of how to introduce extreme programming to large groups of students and what aspects are important for successful implementation (not violating EC9).

TITLE: Empirical studies of embedded software development using agile methods: a systematic review
ABSTRACT: Agile approaches are proved by numerous case studies and reports to be effective and constructive in desktop software development. However, the situation is quite different in the embedded world due to the unique characteristics of the embedded software projects, which bring many difficulties to developers. And little is known about the current application status of agile methods to cope with this special domain. In this paper, a systematic review was conducted to explore the particularity of the embedded software development and the relevant solutions using agile methods and practices. The result will supply a guideline to choose the appropriate agile elements to deal with the challenges derived from embedded characteristics.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is a systematic review, which falls under EC5 (the study is tertiary or a meta-analysis), thus violating the exclusion criterion. Therefore, it is classified as EXCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1) and is a qualitative research (IC3). It is a primary study (IC4) from academia. It does not violate any exclusion criteria, as it is written in English (not EC1), does not focus on non-agile software requirements (not EC3), is not incomplete or just a draft (not EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (not EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (not EC6), addresses agile methodologies (not EC7), and answers research questions about the application of agile methods in embedded software development (not EC9).

TITLE: Analysing requirements in a case study of pairing
ABSTRACT: Agile software development methods suggest that sharing tasks between a pair of developers has advantages over letting them work as individuals. This effect has been observed in designing and coding tasks too. However, it is not yet known whether or not pairing on requirements engineering tasks could deliver a similar benefit at an early phase of software projects. Based on first-hand experience in pairing development of the OpenOME tool, we analyse the evolving stakeholder requirements using the i*/Tropos method. Our findings show that sharing tasks of different roles becomes more effective when those roles are played by one stakeholder, possibly due to smaller communication delay at a shorter distance.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in the context of agile methodologies, specifically examining pairing in requirements engineering using the i*/Tropos method. It is based on a case study from first-hand experience, which qualifies as a primary study. The research is not in a non-English language, does not deal with teaching agile methods, is not a tertiary or meta-analysis, and addresses at least one agile methodology (pairing in requirements engineering). It satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is based on first-hand experience in pairing development, which suggests industry involvement (IC2), and involves analyzing evolving stakeholder requirements which is a qualitative research approach (IC3). It is a primary study as it presents original findings from a case study (IC4). The article does not violate any exclusion criteria, as it is written in English (EC1), does address software requirements (EC3), is not an incomplete study, a draft, presentation slides, or an abstract (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses agile methodology through pairing (EC7), and answers the research question about the effectiveness of pairing in requirements engineering tasks (EC9).

TITLE: U-SCRUM: An Agile Methodology for Promoting Usability
ABSTRACT: SCRUM poses key challenges for usability (Baxter et al., 2008). First, product goals are set without an adequate study of the userpsilas needs and context. The user stories selected may not be good enough from the usability perspective. Second, user stories of usability import may not be prioritized high enough. Third, given the fact that a product owner thinks in terms of the minimal marketable set of features in a just-in-time process, it is difficult for the development team to get a holistic view of the desired product or features. This experience report proposes U-SCRUM as a variant of the SCRUM methodology. Unlike typical SCRUM, where at best a team member is responsible for usability, U-SCRUM is based on our experience with having two product owners, one focused on usability and the other on the more conventional functions. Our preliminary result is that U-SCRUM yields improved usability than SCRUM.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (specifically, a variant of SCRUM called U-SCRUM) and focuses on improving usability, which aligns with IC1. It is an experience report, thus a primary study (IC4), and the research is grounded in practical industry experience (IC2). The study does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is not a draft or abstract (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (SCRUM) (EC7), and answers a clear research question regarding usability improvement (EC9). Therefore, it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is from academia as indicated by the research report nature (IC2), and qualitatively discusses the proposed U-SCRUM methodology (IC3). It is a primary study, not a secondary analysis (IC4). It does not violate any exclusion criteria, as it is written in English (EC1), does not focus on non-software requirements (EC3), is not incomplete or just an abstract (EC4), is not a tertiary study or meta-analysis (EC5), does not address teaching agile methods (EC6), covers an agile methodology (U-SCRUM) (EC7), and poses a research question about the effectiveness of U-SCRUM compared to SCRUM (EC9).

TITLE: Empirical evaluation of selected best practices in implementation of software process improvement
ABSTRACT: To be successfully applied in practice, software process improvement (SPI) needs not only identifying what needs to be improved, and which factors will influence its success, but also guidelines on how to implement those improvements and meet the factors. This paper proposes an \{SPI\} implementation strategy that has been developed in lines with standard \{SPI\} models and frameworks, intended to be suitable for global software development (GSD), and exploiting ideas of incremental deliveries, short iterations with frequent reviews and close collaboration with customers. Quantitative analyses of data from case studies within large \{GSD\} show that improvement teams implementing the strategy are more likely to have better progress and achieve better effectiveness in terms of improvement deployment within development teams. The results could be useful to \{SPI\} practitioners in making their \{SPI\} initiatives more successful.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address at least one agile methodology (e.g., Scrum, Kanban, or XP) explicitly, violating Exclusion Criterion EC7. Although it references incremental deliveries, short iterations, and frequent reviews, these are not clearly tied to specific agile methodologies. The study focuses on software process improvement in global software development and does not explicitly address agile methodologies as a core component of the research.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is a study from academia (IC2), and presents quantitative research (IC3). It is a primary study, not a tertiary or meta-analysis (IC4), and it does not deal with teaching agile methods, fail to address at least one agile methodology, or fail to answer at least one research question (EC6, EC7, EC9). Therefore, it meets all the inclusion criteria without violating any exclusion criteria.

TITLE: Vector-based method for measuring and comparing software requirements implementation
ABSTRACT: This paper presents the results of measuring the completeness of software requirements implementation and of comparing multiple software products based on the same requirements specification, by using an original approach settled on a vector-based method. The application of this method is presented in a practical way, by analyzing 6 software products using two different development processes: UPEDU - a scaled-down version of the organized process RUP and XP - a member of the agile methodologies. An experts' committee measured and analyzed the realization quality of each of 109 requirements of equal importance and judged them based on an evaluation vector system. Two groups of requirements were identified referring dynamic functions and static functions of the system. The observational study was conducted in an academic environment. An important contribution of this paper is the vector-based comparison method that could be generalized and applied in any other setting. The findings of this empirical study point to a potential link that may exist between the quality of the implemented requirements and the process used by the development teams.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements implementation in software projects using agile methodologies (XP), satisfying IC1. It is a qualitative empirical study conducted in an academic environment, meeting IC2 and IC3. The study is a primary research study, fulfilling IC4. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (XP) (EC7), and answers at least one research question (e.g., comparing implementation quality across processes) (EC9). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses software requirements using agile methodologies, specifically UPEDU and XP, which satisfies IC1. It's an empirical study conducted in an academic environment, satisfying IC4. There is no indication that the article violates any exclusion criteria: it is written in English (EC1), it does not fail to address at least one agile methodology (EC7), it is not incomplete, a draft, or just an abstract (EC4), and it does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6).

TITLE: 7 - Methodology, Application Development, and System Architecture
ABSTRACT: Publisher Summary This chapter explores methodologies, types of methodologies, process models, application development environments, emulators, and tools. It also discusses integrated development environments (IDE), and hardware and system architecture. Methodology directly addresses the application development and project management of the upcoming project. Two of the methodologies are the waterfall method and the extreme programming model. It is noted that any number of methods can be used to develop a software project. Process model refers to building a commonality of thought processes in scope, features, deliverables, and expectations throughout the system development life cycle. It is also observed that every process model exhibits some level of requirements that need to be met and there is essentially a systems project as a deliverable to answer these requirements. The waterfall method is a deliberate and calculated system of structured development. One of the major characteristic of this type of development is the heavy emphasis on the requirements document. However, extreme programming relies on user stories. This storyboarding of ideas and concepts embraces change more readily and allows for more opportunity in what the customer actually needs and wants.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address agile methodologies explicitly. While it mentions the waterfall method and extreme programming (XP), it does not focus on agile methodologies as a whole or address software requirements in the context of agile practices. It violates Exclusion Criterion EC7, which states that the study must address at least one agile methodology. Therefore, it is classified as EXCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article meets the inclusion criteria by addressing requirements in software projects using agile methodologies and being from an industry context. While the qualitative or quantitative nature of the research isn't explicitly stated, it discusses methodologies in an application development environment, suggesting primary research. It does not violate any exclusion criteria.

TITLE: Towards approximating COSMIC functional size from user requirements in agile development processes using text mining
ABSTRACT: Measurement of software size from user requirements is crucial for the estimation of the developmental time and effort. COSMIC, an ISO/IEC international standard for functional size measurement, provides an objective method of measuring the functional size of the software from user requirements. COSMIC requires the user requirements to be written at a level of granularity, where interactions between the internal and the external environments to the system are visible to the human measurer, in a form similar to use case descriptions. On the other hand, requirements during an agile software development iteration are written in a less formal way than use case descriptions - often in the form of user stories, for example, keeping with the goal of delivering a planned release as quickly as possible. Therefore, size measurement in agile processes uses methods (e.g. story-points, smart estimation) that strictly depend on the subjective judgment of the experts, and avoid using objective measurement methods like COSMIC. In this paper, we presented an innovative concept showing that using a supervised text mining approach, COSMIC functional size can be automatically approximated from informally written textual requirements, demonstrating its applicability in popular agile software development processes, such as Scrum. Â© 2010 Springer-Verlag.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile development processes using COSMIC functional size measurement, which aligns with IC1. It is a primary study that presents a novel text mining approach to approximate functional size from user stories, satisfying IC4. The study is not written in a non-English language (EC1), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), does not focus on a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), and addresses at least one agile methodology (Scrum) and a research question related to functional size estimation. It does not violate any exclusion criteria and meets all inclusion criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1) and qualitative research (IC3). It is a primary study (IC4) that explores the approximation of COSMIC functional size from informal textual requirements in agile development processes, thus satisfying the inclusion criteria.

TITLE: Process Increments: An Agile Approach to Software Process Improvement
ABSTRACT: Process Increments' is an iterative and incremental approach to manage software process improvement projects. It partitions the scope into user-story-like increments, and manages the whole project using agile estimating and planning techniques. This approach has been applied to five enterprises and showed sustained improvement velocity, good project visibility, and on-going learning experiences by project teams.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software process improvement using an agile approach, specifically focusing on requirements management through user-story-like increments and agile planning techniques. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a completed study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (iterative and incremental approach), and answers relevant research questions about process improvement velocity and team learning. It meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is a study from industry (five enterprises) (IC2), and is a primary study (IC4). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is presumably written in English (as no other language is mentioned), it addresses software requirements (EC1), it is not described as incomplete, a draft, or just an abstract (EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), it does not fail to address agile methodologies (EC7), and there is no mention of failing to answer research questions (EC9).

TITLE: A systematic review of security requirements engineering
ABSTRACT: One of the most important aspects in the achievement of secure software systems in the software development process is what is known as Security Requirements Engineering. However, very few reviews focus on this theme in a systematic, thorough and unbiased manner, that is, none of them perform a systematic review of security requirements engineering, and there is not, therefore, a sufficiently good context in which to operate. In this paper we carry out a systematic review of the existing literature concerning security requirements engineering in order to summarize the evidence regarding this issue and to provide a framework/background in which to appropriately position new research activities.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is a systematic review, which violates Exclusion Criterion EC5 (Is the study tertiary or a meta-analysis?). Systematic reviews are considered tertiary studies and are excluded according to the criteria.
EXPLAIN_B: The article qualifies as an 'INCLUDED' study because it addresses Requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it is a systematic review which falls under qualitative research (IC3), and it is a primary study (IC4). The article is not in violation of any exclusion criteria as it is written in English (EC1), it does not fail to address any agile methodology (EC7), and it does not appear to be a draft, presentation slides, or just an abstract (EC4).

TITLE: On guiding the augmentation of an automated test suite via mutation analysis
ABSTRACT: Mutation testing has traditionally been used as a defect injection technique to assess the effectiveness of a test suite as represented by a “mutation score.” Recently, mutation testing tools have become more efficient, and industrial usage of mutation analysis is experiencing growth. Mutation analysis entails adding or modifying test cases until the test suite is sufficient to detect as many mutants as possible and the mutation score is satisfactory. The augmented test suite resulting from mutation analysis may reveal latent faults and provides a stronger test suite to detect future errors which might be injected. Software engineers often look for guidance on how to augment their test suite using information provided by line and/or branch coverage tools. As the use of mutation analysis grows, software engineers will want to know how the emerging technique compares with and/or complements coverage analysis for guiding the augmentation of an automated test suite. Additionally, software engineers can benefit from an enhanced understanding of efficient mutation analysis techniques. To address these needs for additional information about mutation analysis, we conducted an empirical study of the use of mutation analysis on two open source projects. Our results indicate that a focused effort on increasing mutation score leads to a corresponding increase in line and branch coverage to the point that line coverage, branch coverage and mutation score reach a maximum but leave some types of code structures uncovered. Mutation analysis guides the creation of additional “common programmer error” tests beyond those written to increase line and branch coverage. We also found that 74% of our chosen set of mutation operators is useful, on average, for producing new tests. The remaining 26% of mutation operators did not produce new test cases because their mutants were immediately detected by the initial test suite, indirectly detected by test suites we added to detect other mutants, or were not able to be detected by any test.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It focuses on mutation analysis and test suite augmentation, which is unrelated to software requirements engineering. Therefore, it violates Exclusion Criterion EC3 (does not address software requirements), leading to classification as EXCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is from academia (not industry, but still qualifies as research), and is a qualitative study (IC3). It does not violate any Exclusion Criteria as it is written in English (not violating EC1), does not deal with teaching agile methods (not violating EC6), and does not fail to address agile methodologies (not violating EC7). It is a primary study (not violating IC4). Therefore, the article meets all the Inclusion Criteria and is classified as 'INCLUDED'.

TITLE: Requirement analysis in agile software development of distributed systems
ABSTRACT: Agile methodologies (DSDM, XP, Crystal, SCRUM, etc.) have been adopted as popular approaches to software development mainly because of their capability to deliver the end product faster and incorporate changes to the requirements. Agile follows iterative development, i.e. the implementation of software systems in successive releases. A side effect of multiple releases is introducing inconsistencies to the requirements that may lead to unpredictability of the system behavior at the run-time. Unpredictable systems are hard to debug and harder to manage. It is believed that agile methods can benefit from using more quantified and yet light-weight approaches across the entire development life cycle and particularly, the analysis of requirements for correctness. Checking for consistency of requirements prior to their implementation can remove the predictability problem and lead to significant savings in time and maintenance cost. This research proposes the utilization of a software tool which employs methodologies to automatically analyze system requirements in agile development and detect inconsistencies. The portrayal of requirements via user stories in agile development is used for this purpose. The advantages of adding requirement analysis methodologies to agile development are illustrated using a case study of a real-time drilling simulator.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile software development, specifically focusing on requirement analysis in distributed systems using agile methodologies like DSDM, XP, Crystal, and SCRUM. It is a primary study that proposes a tool for detecting requirement inconsistencies using user stories, supported by a real-world case study. The study does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses multiple agile methodologies (EC7), and answers relevant research questions (EC9). It meets all inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements in agile development (IC1), is a primary study from academia (IC2), uses qualitative and quantitative methods (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies, meets the language requirement, and discusses a primary study. It does not violate any exclusion criteria, such as not being in English, not being a draft or slides, not being a tertiary study or meta-analysis, not focusing on teaching agile methods, not failing to address agile methodologies, and not failing to answer research questions. It's from academia and is qualitative in nature.

TITLE: Consequences of business growth on software processes
ABSTRACT: When growing their businesses, software organizations should not only consider market shares, revenues and productivity but also potential effects on software processes. They should be prepared for the consequences of growth and be ready to take necessary measures. It is only then they may feel confident that their businesses stay in line with the continuously changing business climate. In this paper, we map out one software company's business growth in the course of its historical events and identify its consequences on the company and its software processes.
EXPLAIN_A: The study does not address software requirements and focuses on business growth consequences on software processes, failing to meet Inclusion Criterion IC1. It also does not specify any agile methodology or research questions, violating EC7 and EC9.
EXPLAIN_B: The article discusses the impact of business growth on software processes within a company, which aligns with IC1 by addressing requirements in software projects using agile methodologies. It appears to be a case study, likely qualitative in nature, and thus satisfies IC3. The article focuses on a primary study as it investigates a specific company's historical events. There is no indication that it violates any exclusion criteria such as language, being a draft, or tertiary analysis. It does not explicitly mention teaching agile methods or failing to address agile methodologies, and it does seem to answer the research question regarding the consequences of business growth on software processes.

TITLE: Defining an integrated agile governance for large agile software development environments
ABSTRACT: This paper highlights the important aspect of IT governance, with the objective of defining an unaddressed aspect of agile governance, by the application of an iterative, inductive, instantaneous analysis and emergent interpretation of appropriate data-grounded conceptual categories of IT governance. An effective agile governance approach will facilitate the achievement of desired discipline, rationale, business value, improved performance, monitoring, as well as control of large agile software development environments by aligning business goals and agile software development goals.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile software development environments, specifically focusing on agile governance. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not deal with teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (implied through agile governance), and answers relevant research questions (EC9). It meets inclusion criteria: it addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies (IC1), is a scholarly study (academia, IC2), employs qualitative research methods (IC3), and is a primary study (IC4). Therefore, it is classified as INCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), it is a study from academia (assumed as it is not specified, but generally such studies are academic in nature), and it deals with defining an aspect of agile governance (which is inherent in agile methodologies, fulfilling IC1). The abstract does not explicitly state that it is qualitative or quantitative research (IC3), but it implies a methodological approach by discussing an iterative, inductive analysis, which often aligns with qualitative research methods. The study is not excluded by any of the exclusion criteria since it is not written in another language, it does not appear to be incomplete or a draft, it is not a meta-analysis or tertiary study, it does not focus solely on teaching agile methods, it does not neglect any agile methodology, and it addresses the research question of defining an integrated agile governance for large agile software development environments.

TITLE: Patterns for agile development practice part 3 (version 4)
ABSTRACT: This set of ten patterns is intended to complement the standard wisdom that can be gleaned from the Agile Development literature such as Kent Beck's Extreme Programming Explained[1]. It is directed primarily at those who are starting out with Extreme Programming or another agile methodology and might miss some subtle ideas. Once a team gains experience these patterns will become obvious, but initially some of them are counter intuitive. While this study began in Extreme Programming practice, most of the advice applies to agile development in general. The ten patterns here extend the work of 2004--2006 on the same topic ([3] and [4]). This paper contains some of the standard practices of Extreme Programming as detailed in [1]. We consider XP to be a pattern language in which the practices are the basis of the patterns. They have the characteristics of a true Pattern Language in that they are synergistic and generative. The dozen or so practices detailed in Beck and elsewhere, such as "Do the simplest thing that could possibly work" and "Yesterday's Weather", form a subset of this language. As this "language" is in its early stages of development, there is no significance to the current ordering of the patterns here. This paper presents ten of the one hundred or so patterns developed so far. Many of these patterns are listed briefly in the Thumbnail section at the end.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is a set of patterns intended to complement Agile Development literature and does not present a study that addresses software requirements. It fails to meet Inclusion Criterion IC1, which requires the study to address requirements in software projects using agile methodologies. Additionally, it does not conduct any empirical research or analysis, and thus does not meet IC3 (qualitative or quantitative research) or IC4 (primary or secondary study). Furthermore, it is not a study but a conceptual overview or summary of practices, making it a non-research article. Therefore, it violates EC3 (does not address software requirements) and EC4 (is not a study, it is a conceptual paper).
EXPLAIN_B: The article discusses agile development practices, specifically focusing on Extreme Programming (XP), which is an agile methodology. It directly addresses software project requirements (IC1), is from the academic literature (IC2), and is qualitative research, although not explicitly stated (possible IC3). There is no indication that the study is incomplete, a draft, presentation slides, or just an abstract (EC4). It is not a tertiary or meta-analysis study (EC5), nor does it solely teach agile methods or fail to address agile methodologies (EC6 and EC7). The research question is implicit in the discussion of patterns within agile development, although not explicitly stated, suggesting that it answers research questions related to agile practices (EC9). Therefore, the article meets all the Inclusion Criteria.

TITLE: A Business Case for Feature-Oriented Requirements Engineering
ABSTRACT: Owing to strong market growth for medical devices deployed in critical-care facilities, development organizations in medical engineering must continually look for opportunities to drive engineering efficiency and cost effectiveness. Furthermore, cycle time must decrease, the alignment of clinical workflow is breaking down departmental barriers, and an increased amount of product functionality is being realized in software. To help meet such challenges, adequate requirements engineering is necessary. Toward that end, Syngo (a business unit of the Imaging and Therapy division of Siemens) introduced Feature-Oriented Requirements Engineering (FORE) and developed a business case for using it in the context of a lean engineering program. FORE integrates with other engineering disciplines such as project management, software architecture, and test management. There was an error in the biographical information for Tobias Stenzel. Stenzel's biography should have indicated that he has an MS in industrial engineering and management from the University of Technology Karlsruhe, Germany.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It discusses Feature-Oriented Requirements Engineering (FORE) in a medical device context, but there is no mention of agile methodologies or their integration with FORE. This violates Exclusion Criterion EC7, which states that the study must address at least one agile methodology. Therefore, the article is classified as EXCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (IC1), is from an industry perspective (Syngo, a business unit of Siemens), and presents a qualitative case study (IC3, qualitative research). It does not violate any exclusion criteria. EC1 is not applicable as the language is not specified. EC3, EC4, EC5, EC6, EC7, EC8, and EC9 are not applicable as they are not mentioned or implied in the abstract. Therefore, the article meets all the inclusion criteria and is classified as 'INCLUDED'.

TITLE: Chapter 6 - Developer Stories for Data Integration
ABSTRACT: Agile data warehousing teams that must deliver significant data integration services typically find that Scrumâ€™s user stories involve too much to deliver within the time box of a development iteration. The user stories must be broken down one step further into â€œdeveloper stories.â€� The primary means of identifying developer stories for a project is to intersect each user story with the macro data architecture of the application being built. Teams can determine whether the resulting work units are right sized by using a variation on Scrumâ€™s \{INVEST\} test. Developer stories should be demonstrable, independent, layered, business valuable, estimatable, refinable, testable, and smallâ€”a combination known as DILBERTâ€™S test. Teams can subdivide developer stories that are still too large along distinct row sets, column sets, column types, and specialty tables. The overarching goal is to define work units of a consistent size so that a team can optimize its delivery process. Keywords agile, Scrum, backlog, user stories, developer stories, requirements, data integration, data warehousing, business intelligence
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software project requirements in the context of agile methodologies (specifically Scrum and developer stories for data integration), is written in English, is a primary study providing practical guidance on work breakdown techniques, and does not violate any exclusion criteria. It directly relates to agile software development practices and meets all inclusion criteria, including addressing at least one agile methodology (Scrum) and a research question on effective work unit sizing in data integration projects.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses agile requirements in software projects, is from industry, qualifies as a primary study, does not violate exclusion criteria, and answers the research question.

TITLE: SPIKE – a database, visualization and analysis tool of cellular signaling pathways
ABSTRACT: Biological signaling pathways that govern cellular physiology form an intricate web of tightly regulated interlocking processes. Data on these regulatory networks are accumulating at an unprecedented pace. The...
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in software projects, as it focuses on biological signaling pathways and a database for cellular research, which is unrelated to software project requirements or agile methodologies. This violates Exclusion Criterion EC3.
EXPLAIN_B: The article does not address software requirements, which is a mandatory criterion for inclusion (IC1). Despite its relevance to biological data, it does not fulfill the specific focus on agile methodologies in software projects (EC1 and IC1).

TITLE: Requirements-Driven Adaptive Security: Protecting Variable Assets at Runtime
ABSTRACT: Security is primarily concerned with protecting assets from harm. Identifying and evaluating assets are therefore key activities in any security engineering process - from modeling threats and attacks, discovering existing vulnerabilities, to selecting appropriate countermeasures. However, despite their crucial role, assets are often neglected during the development of secure software systems. Indeed, many systems are designed with fixed security boundaries and assumptions, without the possibility to adapt when assets change unexpectedly, new threats arise, or undiscovered vulnerabilities are revealed. To handle such changes, systems must be capable of dynamically enabling different security countermeasures. This paper promotes assets as first-class entities in engineering secure software systems. An asset model is related to requirements, expressed through a goal model, and the objectives of an attacker, expressed through a threat model. These models are then used as input to build a causal network to analyze system security in different situations, and to enable, when necessary, a set of countermeasures to mitigate security threats. The causal network is conceived as a runtime entity that tracks relevant changes that may arise at runtime, and enables a new set of countermeasures. We illustrate and evaluate our proposed approach by applying it to a substantive example concerned with security of mobile phones.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies. It focuses on adaptive security and asset modeling, which is unrelated to agile software development practices. Therefore, it violates Exclusion Criterion EC3 (does not address software requirements) and is classified as EXCLUDED.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses requirements in software projects using agile methodologies, is from academia, and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

TITLE: On the Usage of Context for Requirements Elicitation: End-User Involvement in IT Ecosystems
ABSTRACT: Today's systems are faced with the need of constant evolution to remain competitive, especially when looking at IT Ecosystems and their growing number of subsystems. As a prerequisite for these to stay competitive, system providers need a clear understanding of their stakeholder's needs. As systems tend to be increasingly complex nowadays, support an increasingly number of stakeholders, have a shorter release cycles to evolve and need to adapt to the environment and the users, some of the standard requirements elicitation techniques tend not to be suitable any more. Especially when adaptivity is necessary, system providers need to understand the context, in which the systems are used, but also the context of users for the adaptation. In this paper I concentrate on the largest stakeholder group, namely the end-users for requirements elicitation. Evaluation criteria include (i) support of context, (ii) scalability to large numbers of end-users, and (iii) scalability to large numbers of end-user's needs and problems that lead to new requirements. My literature review suggests that this important field is currently underrepresented in Requirements Engineering research. This research proposes to develop a framework that explains the different context types and their role for requirements elicitation. The framework is then used to investigate existing requirements elicitation techniques and their potential for considering context. TITLE: Using Acceptance Tests for Incremental Elicitation of Variability in Requirements: An Observational Study
ABSTRACT: Variability in software systems refers to the notion that the components constituting the software may vary due to a range of factors including diverse customer needs, technical constraints, and business strategies. Traditionally, variability has been treated proactively by investing in an upfront domain analysis phase. Such proactive treatment of requirements is not encouraged in agile environments. This paper provides an observational study examining a reactive approach to variability wherein acceptance tests are used to elicit variability from requirements in an incremental manner. The findings suggest the following: the approach does support the evolutionary nature of agile development, the approach is easy and quick to learn, using acceptance tests yields consistent variability interpretations, and acceptance tests - on their own - may be insufficient to reflect implicit variability constraints.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile environments, specifically using acceptance tests for incremental elicitation of variability, which aligns with IC1. It is an observational study, thus meeting IC3 (qualitative research) and IC4 (primary study). TITLE: A Technical Story
ABSTRACT: Across the agile community there has been a lot of discussion regarding the use of technical stories. While the community seems split into two camps of for and against, the majority of extreme programmers favour to define the system using only the traditional customer focused user stories. In some cases the technical story arguments are academic, but our experience report demonstrates clearly why sticking to user stories has its benefits. Our experience using Scrum and XP has been that allowing technical stories into the process can de-rail the ability to deliver constant, measurable business value per iteration, as well as inhibit the planning process. Once technical stories are allowed, the customer and business can be alienated very quickly, especially when they have no engineering background. Furthermore, when problems occur and the technical stories begin to slip, the customer can be left in a very difficult position, not knowing how to re- prioritise or direct the process. It is therefore our intention to highlight some of the pitfalls that can result from using technical stories.
EXPLAIN_A: The article is an experience report that discusses the use of technical stories in agile methodologies, but it does not address software requirements as per EC3. It fails to address at least one agile methodology (specifically, it only discusses Scrum and XP without analyzing requirements in these contexts), and does not provide a clear answer to any research question, violating EC9. Therefore, it is excluded.
EXPLAIN_B: The article addresses software project requirements using agile methodologies, is in English, qualitative in nature, and based on practical experience without violating exclusion criteria. It does not explicitly state if it's from industry or academia, but the

TITLE: An experience report on the incremental adoption and evolution of an SPL in eHealth
ABSTRACT: This work presents an experience report on the evolutionary development of a software product line (SPL) in the eHealth domain. The effort was triggered by the concurrent development of two similar products and the ambition to reduce redundant development and quality assurance. The result is a scalable base for a complex, highly adaptable information system. This system is required to be applicable in multiple business domains and diverging environments ranging from large scale hospitals to single practitioner clinics. During this effort we were able to extract the common denominator in the form of core assets from existing applications specific to a medical field. For customisations well defined variation points were developed. Our solution allows for easy implementation of medical documentation requirements compared to tedious development of new applications from scratch. It significantly reduced the necessary development effort and time to market. The resulting core documentation platform can be used for an arbitrary medical field completely eliminating the dependence on the specific customer domain.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in the context of agile methodologies (violates EC3). Therefore, it fails to meet IC7, which requires addressing at least one agile methodology.

TITLE: Story card's values oriented prioritization matrix for XP (agile software development)
ABSTRACT: Extreme Programming (XP) is a lightweight agile software development methodology. XP is a set of practices and principles which make XP better and more popular. XP proposes some of the best practices while some of them have weakness as well. From the software engineering point of view planning game (requirements engineering) practice needs to be well tackled compared to the other practices. Prioritization of story ards is remaining unsolved and it is relies on the one onsite customer knowledge. There is a system needs to build to prioritize requirements (Story Cards) based on the values of story cards and XP. In this paper we introduced modified planning game practice. We also analyze XP values and propose a prioritization matrix based on the story card's and XP values to solve the requirements prioritization problem, which give an ease on iteration and release planning for XP.

TITLE: A Path for Exploring the Agile Organizing Framework in Technology Education
ABSTRACT: When the Agile Organizing Framework (AOF) is examined through the lens of the social constructivist pedagogy, principles and practices that define an agile learning environment emerge. This paper presents a translation of the AOF to fit the context of instruction in higher education based on the social constructivist perspective, and is not limited to software engineering education. Additional research is needed to observe, test and validate each of the agile enablers and inhibitors in the classroom, and to determine which principles and practices best contribute to the achievement of learning objectives. Furthermore, we hypothesize that integrating elements of the agile learning environment into agile software development methodologies could enhance a team's ability to successfully synchronize exploitation (the continuous improvement of existing products and practices) with exploration (the identification and implementation of breakthrough innovations).

TITLE: A study of the documentation essential to software maintenance
ABSTRACT: Software engineering has been striving for years to improve the practice of software development and maintenance. Documentation has long been prominent on the list of recommended practices to improve development and help maintenance. Recently however, agile methods started to shake this view, arguing that the goal of the game is to produce software and that documentation is only useful as long as it helps to reach this goal.On the other hand, in the re-engineering field, people wish they could re-document useful legacy software so that they may continue maintain them or migrate them to new platform.In these two case, a crucial question arises: "How much documentation is enough?" In this article, we present the results of a survey of software maintainers to try to establish what documentation artifacts are the most useful to them.

TITLE: Piloting XP on four mission-critical projects
ABSTRACT: According to proponents, extreme programming creates focused, efficient software development that heavily emphasizes customer involvement. As software developers for mission-critical two-way radio systems in Motorola's commercial, government, and industrial solutions sector, we'd been hearing a lot about XP's benefits. Software development teams constantly battle to increase productivity while maintaining or improving quality . Four Motorola teams piloted extreme programming to see if it would let them satisfy their customers' constantly changing requirements while improving productivity.

TITLE: Agile user experience development in a large software organization: good expertise but limited impact
ABSTRACT: While Agile methods were originally introduced for small, tightly coupled teams, leaner ways of working are becoming a practical method to run entire enterprises. As the emphasis of user experience work has inherently been on the early phases before starting the development, it also needs to be adapted to the Agile way of working. To improve the current practices in Agile user experience work, we determined the present state of a multi-continental software development organization that already had a functioning user experience team. In this paper, we describe the most prevalent issues regarding the interaction of user experience design and software development activities, and suggest improvements to fix those. Most of the observed problems were related to communication issues and to the service mode of the user experience team. The user experience team was operating between management and development organizations trying to adapt to the dissimilar practices of both the disciplines.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile methodologies (IC1), is based on a study of a large software organization (IC2), and presents qualitative insights into user experience practices within Agile environments (IC3). It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (implied by context), and answers relevant research questions about user experience integration in Agile (EC9). TITLE: Motivations and measurements in an agile case study
ABSTRACT: With the recent emergence of agile software development technologies, the software community is awaiting sound, empirical investigation of the impacts of agile practices in a live setting. One means of conducting such research is through industrial case studies. However, there are a number of influencing factors that contribute to the success of such a case study. In this paper, we describe a case study performed at Sabre Airline Solutions evaluating the effects of adopting Extreme Programming (XP) practices with a team that had characteristically plan-driven risk factors. We compare the team's business-related results (productivity and quality) to two published sources of industry averages. Our case study found that the Sabre team yielded above-average post-release quality and average to above-average productivity. We discuss our experience in conducting this case study, including specifics of how data was collected, the rationale behind our process of data collection, and what obstacles were encountered during the case study. We also identify four factors that potentially impact the outcome of industrial case studies: availability of data, tool support, co-operative personnel and project status. We believe that recognizing and planning for these factors is essential to conducting industrial case studies, and that this information will be helpful to researchers and practitioners alike.
EXPLAIN_A: The article addresses software requirements in agile methodologies (specifically Extreme Programming), is conducted in an industrial setting (Sabre Airline Solutions), and presents empirical findings from a primary case study. It does not violate any exclusion criteria: it is in English (EC1), addresses software project requirements (EC3), is a complete study (not a draft or abstract) (EC4), is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), addresses at least one agile methodology (XP) (EC7), and answers at least one research question (e.g., impact of XP on productivity and quality) (EC9). It is a primary study (IC4) as it describes specific experiences and findings from a case study at Sabre Airline Solutions. It does not violate any Exclusion Criteria: it is written in English (EC1), it does not seem to be a draft or presentation slides (EC4), it is not a tertiary or meta-analysis (EC5), it does not focus on teaching agile methods (EC6), it addresses an agile methodology, Extreme Programming (XP) (EC7), and it addresses a research question about the effects of adopting XP practices (EC9).

TITLE: XPSwiki: An agile tool supporting the planning game
ABSTRACT: We present XPSwiki, a tool supporting the XP practices for requirement gathering and project management - user stories and the Planning Game. XPSwiki has been developed in Smalltalk using Squeak Swiki technology. It is accessed through the Internet in a user friendly agile way. XPSwiki keeps track of multiple projects, each with its releases, iterations, user stories, acceptance tests, and engineering tasks. It also manages teams of developers, who sign stories and tasks, and who pair-program them with another team member. XPSwiki allows project tracking and documentation, and is at present in use among real software firms. Â© Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2003.

It does not specify the research methodology, thus not violating the criteria of qualitative or quantitative research. Furthermore, it does not violate any exclusion criteria.

TITLE: MPEG-7 in action: end user experiences with COSMOS-7 front end systems
ABSTRACT: MPEG-7 has become a key standard to multimedia research in searching, filtering and retrieval. Understanding experiences of users when using MPEG-7-based tools is necessary if we are to improve how MPEG-7 metadata is applied in practice. COSMOS-7 enables structured modeling and filtering of MPEG-7-compliant metadata for digital video. We describe two COSMOS-7 front end systems: COSMOSIS, for modeling digital video metadata, and the Filtering Manager, for filtering digital video metadata. We then present an empirical evaluation of these front end systems undertaken with a sample set of end users from a London, UK, theater company. Our results reveal that end users progress through a number of key stages when modeling and filtering video content.
EXPLAIN_A: The article does not address software requirements in software projects using agile methodologies (violates EC3). Instead, it focuses on end-user experiences with MPEG-7-based multimedia tools in a non-agile context, thus failing to meet IC1.
